trans-unit.source: Handle conflicts with offline data in Mobile Services (Windows Phone) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Handle conflicts with offline data in Mobile Services (Windows Phone) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services handle conflicts when syncing offline data in your Windows phone application
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services handle conflicts when syncing offline data in your Windows phone application

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to synchronize data and handle conflicts when using the offline capabilities of Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to synchronize data and handle conflicts when using the offline capabilities of Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will download an app that supports both offline and online data, integrate the mobile service with the app, and then login to the Azure Management Portal to view and update the database when running the app.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will download an app that supports both offline and online data, integrate the mobile service with the app, and then login to the Azure Management Portal to view and update the database when running the app.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial builds on the steps and the sample app from the previous tutorial [Get started with offline data].
trans-unit.target: This tutorial builds on the steps and the sample app from the previous tutorial [Get started with offline data].

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this tutorial, you must first complete [Get started with offline data].
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this tutorial, you must first complete [Get started with offline data].

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires Visual Studio 2012 and the [Windows Phone 8 SDK].
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires Visual Studio 2012 and the [Windows Phone 8 SDK].

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is built on the [Handling conflicts code sample], which is a Windows Phone 8 project for Visual Studio 2012.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is built on the [Handling conflicts code sample], which is a Windows Phone 8 project for Visual Studio 2012.

trans-unit.source: The UI for this app is similar to the app in the tutorial [Get started with offline data], except that there is a new date column in for each TodoItem.
trans-unit.target: The UI for this app is similar to the app in the tutorial [Get started with offline data], except that there is a new date column in for each TodoItem.

trans-unit.source: Download the Windows Phone version of the [Handling conflicts code sample].
trans-unit.target: Download the Windows Phone version of the [Handling conflicts code sample].

trans-unit.source: Install [SQLite for Windows Phone 8] if it has not been installed.
trans-unit.target: Install [SQLite for Windows Phone 8] if it has not been installed.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2012, open the downloaded project.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2012, open the downloaded project.

trans-unit.source: Add a reference to SQLite for Windows Phone under Windows Phone > Extensions.
trans-unit.target: Add a reference to SQLite for Windows Phone under Windows Phone > Extensions.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2012, press the F5 key to build and run the app in the debugger.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2012, press the F5 key to build and run the app in the debugger.

trans-unit.source: In the app, type some text for some new todo items, then click Save to save each one.
trans-unit.target: In the app, type some text for some new todo items, then click Save to save each one.

trans-unit.source: You can also modify the due date of the todo items you add.
trans-unit.target: You can also modify the due date of the todo items you add.

trans-unit.source: Note that the app is not yet connected to any mobile service, so the buttons Push and Pull will throw exceptions.
trans-unit.target: Note that the app is not yet connected to any mobile service, so the buttons Push and Pull will throw exceptions.

trans-unit.source: In this section you will update the database for your mobile service to include a TodoItem table with a due date column.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will update the database for your mobile service to include a TodoItem table with a due date column.

trans-unit.source: The app allows you to change the due date for an item at runtime so that you can generate sync conflicts in a later section of this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The app allows you to change the due date for an item at runtime so that you can generate sync conflicts in a later section of this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: The TodoItem class in the sample is defined in MainPage.xaml.cs.
trans-unit.target: The TodoItem class in the sample is defined in MainPage.xaml.cs.

trans-unit.source: Notice the class has the following attribute which will target the sync operations against that table.
trans-unit.target: Notice the class has the following attribute which will target the sync operations against that table.

trans-unit.source: Update your database to include this table.
trans-unit.target: Update your database to include this table.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the .NET backend for your mobile service, follow these steps to update the schema for your database.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the .NET backend for your mobile service, follow these steps to update the schema for your database.

trans-unit.source: Open your .NET backend mobile service project in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Open your .NET backend mobile service project in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, in your service project, expand the Models folder and open ToDoItem.cs.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, in your service project, expand the Models folder and open ToDoItem.cs.

trans-unit.source: Add the DueDate property as follows.
trans-unit.target: Add the DueDate property as follows.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, expand the App_Start folder and open the WebApiConfig.cs file.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, expand the App_Start folder and open the WebApiConfig.cs file.

trans-unit.source: In the WebApiConfig.cs file, notice that your default database initializer class is derived from the DropCreateDatabaseIfModelChanges class.
trans-unit.target: In the WebApiConfig.cs file, notice that your default database initializer class is derived from the DropCreateDatabaseIfModelChanges class.

trans-unit.source: This means any change to the model will result in the table being dropped and recreated to accommodate the new model.
trans-unit.target: This means any change to the model will result in the table being dropped and recreated to accommodate the new model.

trans-unit.source: So the data in the table will be lost and the table will be re-seeded.
trans-unit.target: So the data in the table will be lost and the table will be re-seeded.

trans-unit.source: Modify the Seed method of the database initializer so that the Seed() initialization function as follows to initialize the new DueDate column.
trans-unit.target: Modify the Seed method of the database initializer so that the Seed() initialization function as follows to initialize the new DueDate column.

trans-unit.source: Save the WebApiConfig.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Save the WebApiConfig.cs file.

trans-unit.source: When using the default database initializer, Entity Framework will drop and recreate the database whenever it detects a data model change in the Code First model definition.
trans-unit.target: When using the default database initializer, Entity Framework will drop and recreate the database whenever it detects a data model change in the Code First model definition.

trans-unit.source: To make this data model change and maintain existing data in the database, you must use Code First Migrations.
trans-unit.target: To make this data model change and maintain existing data in the database, you must use Code First Migrations.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>How to Use Code First Migrations to Update the Data Model</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>How to Use Code First Migrations to Update the Data Model</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, expand the Controllers folder and open ToDoItemController.cs.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, expand the Controllers folder and open ToDoItemController.cs.

trans-unit.source: Rename the TodoItemController class to TodoWithDateController.
trans-unit.target: Rename the TodoItemController class to TodoWithDateController.

trans-unit.source: This will change the REST endpoint for table operations.
trans-unit.target: This will change the REST endpoint for table operations.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, right click your .NET backend mobile service project and click Publish to publish your changes.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, right click your .NET backend mobile service project and click Publish to publish your changes.

trans-unit.source: For JavaScript backend mobile services, you will add a new table named TodoWithDate.
trans-unit.target: For JavaScript backend mobile services, you will add a new table named TodoWithDate.

trans-unit.source: To add the TodoWithDate table for JavaScript backend mobile services, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: To add the TodoWithDate table for JavaScript backend mobile services, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: Log into the [Azure Management Portal].
trans-unit.target: Log into the [Azure Management Portal].

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the Data tab of your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the Data tab of your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Click Create at the bottom of the page and create a new table named TodoWithDate.
trans-unit.target: Click Create at the bottom of the page and create a new table named TodoWithDate.

trans-unit.source: Now it's time to test the app against Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Now it's time to test the app against Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, find your mobile service's application key by clicking Manage Keys on the command bar of the Dashboard tab.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, find your mobile service's application key by clicking Manage Keys on the command bar of the Dashboard tab.

trans-unit.source: Copy the Application Key.
trans-unit.target: Copy the Application Key.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open the App.xaml.cs file in the client sample project.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open the App.xaml.cs file in the client sample project.

trans-unit.source: Change the initialization of the MobileServiceClient to use your mobile service URL and application key:
trans-unit.target: Change the initialization of the MobileServiceClient to use your mobile service URL and application key:

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to build and run the app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to build and run the app.

trans-unit.source: As before, type text in the textbox, and then click Save to save some new todo items.
trans-unit.target: As before, type text in the textbox, and then click Save to save some new todo items.

trans-unit.source: This saves the data to the local sync table, but not to the server.
trans-unit.target: This saves the data to the local sync table, but not to the server.

trans-unit.source: To see the current state of your database, log into the [Azure Management Portal], click Mobile Services, and then click your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: To see the current state of your database, log into the [Azure Management Portal], click Mobile Services, and then click your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the JavaScript backend for your mobile service, click the Data tab, then click the TodoWithDate table.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the JavaScript backend for your mobile service, click the Data tab, then click the TodoWithDate table.

trans-unit.source: Click Browse to see that the table will still be empty, since we have not pushed changes from the app to the server..
trans-unit.target: Click Browse to see that the table will still be empty, since we have not pushed changes from the app to the server..

trans-unit.source: If you are using the .NET backend for your mobile service, click the Configure tab, then click your SQL database.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the .NET backend for your mobile service, click the Configure tab, then click your SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Click Manage at the bottom of the screen to log into the SQL Azure Managment Portal to view your database by running a SQL query similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: Click Manage at the bottom of the screen to log into the SQL Azure Managment Portal to view your database by running a SQL query similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: Back in the app, click Push.
trans-unit.target: Back in the app, click Push.

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal, click Refresh on the TodoItem table.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal, click Refresh on the TodoItem table.

trans-unit.source: You should now see the data that you entered in your app.
trans-unit.target: You should now see the data that you entered in your app.

trans-unit.source: Leave Emulator WVGA 512MB up and running for the next section where you will run the app in two emulators to generate a conflict.
trans-unit.target: Leave Emulator WVGA 512MB up and running for the next section where you will run the app in two emulators to generate a conflict.

trans-unit.source: In a real world scenario, a sync conflict would occur when one app pushes updates to a record in the database, and then another app tries to push a change to the same record using an outdated version field in that record.
trans-unit.target: In a real world scenario, a sync conflict would occur when one app pushes updates to a record in the database, and then another app tries to push a change to the same record using an outdated version field in that record.

trans-unit.source: If an instance of the app tries to update the same record, without pulling in the updated record, a conflict will occur and be caught as a MobileServicePreconditionFailedException in the app.
trans-unit.target: If an instance of the app tries to update the same record, without pulling in the updated record, a conflict will occur and be caught as a MobileServicePreconditionFailedException in the app.

trans-unit.source: In this section you will run two instances of the app at the same time to generate a conflict.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will run two instances of the app at the same time to generate a conflict.

trans-unit.source: If Emulator WVGA 512MB is not still up and running, press Ctrl+F5 to relaunch it.
trans-unit.target: If Emulator WVGA 512MB is not still up and running, press Ctrl+F5 to relaunch it.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, change the output device to Emulator WVGA and run a second instance of the app in the new emulator by pressing F5.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, change the output device to Emulator WVGA and run a second instance of the app in the new emulator by pressing F5.

trans-unit.source: In the second instance of the app, click Pull to sync the local store with the mobile service database.
trans-unit.target: In the second instance of the app, click Pull to sync the local store with the mobile service database.

trans-unit.source: Both instances of the app should have the same data.
trans-unit.target: Both instances of the app should have the same data.

trans-unit.source: In the second instance of the app, click the check box to complete one of the items then click Push to push your change to the remote database.
trans-unit.target: In the second instance of the app, click the check box to complete one of the items then click Push to push your change to the remote database.

trans-unit.source: In the following screen shot, Pick up James has been completed indicating the James has already been picked up.
trans-unit.target: In the following screen shot, Pick up James has been completed indicating the James has already been picked up.

trans-unit.source: The first instance of the app now has an outdated record.
trans-unit.target: The first instance of the app now has an outdated record.

trans-unit.source: In the first instance of the app, try to change the date for the outdated record then click Push to attempt to update the remote database with the outdated record.
trans-unit.target: In the first instance of the app, try to change the date for the outdated record then click Push to attempt to update the remote database with the outdated record.

trans-unit.source: In the screen shot below, we try to schedule James to be picked up on 5/10/2014.
trans-unit.target: In the screen shot below, we try to schedule James to be picked up on 5/10/2014.

trans-unit.source: When you click the Push button to commit the date change, you will see a dialog box indicating that the conflict has been detected.
trans-unit.target: When you click the Push button to commit the date change, you will see a dialog box indicating that the conflict has been detected.

trans-unit.source: You will be asked how to resolve the conflict.
trans-unit.target: You will be asked how to resolve the conflict.

trans-unit.source: Choose one of the options to resolve the conflict.
trans-unit.target: Choose one of the options to resolve the conflict.

trans-unit.source: In the scenario shown below, James has already been picked up.
trans-unit.target: In the scenario shown below, James has already been picked up.

trans-unit.source: So there's no need to schedule a pick up for him on 5/10/2014.
trans-unit.target: So there's no need to schedule a pick up for him on 5/10/2014.

trans-unit.source: The Use server version option would be selected so the first instance of the app would have that record updated with the record from the server.
trans-unit.target: The Use server version option would be selected so the first instance of the app would have that record updated with the record from the server.

trans-unit.source: In order to set up the offline feature to detect conflicts, you must include a version column in both your local database and your data transfer object.
trans-unit.target: In order to set up the offline feature to detect conflicts, you must include a version column in both your local database and your data transfer object.

trans-unit.source: The class TodoItem has the following member:
trans-unit.target: The class TodoItem has the following member:

trans-unit.source: The column __version is also specified in the local database set up in the OnNavigatedTo() method.
trans-unit.target: The column __version is also specified in the local database set up in the OnNavigatedTo() method.

trans-unit.source: To handle offline sync conflicts in your code, you create a class that implements IMobileServiceSyncHandler.
trans-unit.target: To handle offline sync conflicts in your code, you create a class that implements IMobileServiceSyncHandler.

trans-unit.source: Pass an object of this type in the call to InitializeAsync:
trans-unit.target: Pass an object of this type in the call to InitializeAsync:

trans-unit.source: The class SyncHandler in MainPage.xaml.cs implements IMobileServiceSyncHandler.
trans-unit.target: The class SyncHandler in MainPage.xaml.cs implements IMobileServiceSyncHandler.

trans-unit.source: The method ExecuteTableOperationAsync is called when each push operation is sent to the server.
trans-unit.target: The method ExecuteTableOperationAsync is called when each push operation is sent to the server.

trans-unit.source: If an exception of type MobileServicePreconditionFailedException is thrown, this means that there is a conflict between the local and remote versions of an item.
trans-unit.target: If an exception of type MobileServicePreconditionFailedException is thrown, this means that there is a conflict between the local and remote versions of an item.

trans-unit.source: To resolve conflicts in favor of the local item, you should simply retry the operation.
trans-unit.target: To resolve conflicts in favor of the local item, you should simply retry the operation.

trans-unit.source: Once a conflict has occurred, the local item version will be updated to match the server version, so executing the operation again will overwrite the server changes with the local changes:
trans-unit.target: Once a conflict has occurred, the local item version will be updated to match the server version, so executing the operation again will overwrite the server changes with the local changes:

trans-unit.source: To resolve conflicts in favor of the server item, simply return from the ExecuteTableOperationAsync.
trans-unit.target: To resolve conflicts in favor of the server item, simply return from the ExecuteTableOperationAsync.

trans-unit.source: The local version of the object will be discarded and replaced with the value from the server.
trans-unit.target: The local version of the object will be discarded and replaced with the value from the server.

trans-unit.source: To stop the push operation (but retain the queued changes), use the method AbortPush():
trans-unit.target: To stop the push operation (but retain the queued changes), use the method AbortPush():

trans-unit.source: This will stop the current push operation but will keep all pending changes, including the current operation if AbortPush is called from ExecuteTableOperationAsync.
trans-unit.target: This will stop the current push operation but will keep all pending changes, including the current operation if AbortPush is called from ExecuteTableOperationAsync.

trans-unit.source: The next time that PushAsync() is called, these changes will be sent to the server.
trans-unit.target: The next time that PushAsync() is called, these changes will be sent to the server.

trans-unit.source: When a push is canceled, PushAsync will throw a MobileServicePushFailedException, and the exception property PushResult.Status will have the value MobileServicePushStatus.CancelledByOperation.
trans-unit.target: When a push is canceled, PushAsync will throw a MobileServicePushFailedException, and the exception property PushResult.Status will have the value MobileServicePushStatus.CancelledByOperation.
